chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Corticosteroids - inhaled
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people receiving inhaled corticosteroids in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I consider when initiating inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Select the most appropriate delivery system for the person being treated, their condition, and the drug being prescribed.
  • Ensure that the person knows how to use the device (and check this competence at any review, routine or unscheduled). 
  • Avoid prescribing inhalers generically — this ensures continuity of device type in future and helps prevent adherence issues that may occur if a different device is given. 
  • The various inhaled corticosteroids are similar in efficacy and adverse effect profile. However:
    • Qvar and Kelhale products have extrafine particles and are twice as potent as other beclometasone inhalers. 
  • Issue a steroid treatment card to people: 
    • Using prolonged high doses (more than 1000 micrograms beclometasone or equivalent) of inhaled corticosteroids (including off-label high doses, and maximum inhaled doses in conjunction with oral corticosteroids).
    • Taking inhaled corticosteroids plus drugs that inhibit their metabolism (for example cytochrome P450 inhibitors, such as HIV protease inhibitors).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma [BTS/SIGN, 2019], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Asthma: diagnosis, monitoring and chronic asthma management [NICE, 2020c], and the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) advice High dose inhaled steroids: new advice on supply of steroid treatment cards [MHRA, 2006].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What delivery systems are available for inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pressurized metered-dose inhalers (pMDIs)
    • In a pMDI, the drug is suspended or dissolved in a propellant (hydrofluoroalkane) within a pressurized container. 
    • The device is activated by the user pressing down on the top of the container, resulting in the release of a fine spray containing propellant and drug.
      • The person needs to coordinate inspiration and actuation. 
    • pMDIs are the standard type of inhaler for delivering inhaled corticosteroids, and are generally less expensive than other delivery systems. However, they require adequate coordination and dexterity.
    • If used correctly, they are at least as effective as other delivery systems. 
  • Spacer devices
    • These are plastic devices with a mouthpiece at one end and a hole, for a pMDI to be inserted, at the other end.
    • There are a number of different devices available, but they are not interchangeable and must be compatible with the pMDI used. 
    • Spacers are useful because they: 
      • Remove the need for coordination between actuation of the pMDI and inhalation. 
      • Slow down the particles of the drug and allow more time for evaporation of the propellant so that more of the drug can be inhaled and deposited in the lungs.
      • Reduce the amount of drug deposited in the oropharynx (thereby reducing local adverse effects and the amount of systemic absorption). 
    • Spacers are of particular benefit for: 
      • Children who need high doses of inhaled corticosteroids.
      • People with a poor inhalation technique.
      • People who are prone to candidiasis with inhaled corticosteroids.
  • Dry powder inhalers (DPIs)
    • DPIs do not have a propellant — they deliver the micronized drug and a carrier powder that is inhaled using the person's own inspiratory flow (this requires the person to have sufficient inspiratory effort to breathe in the powder). 
      • Many DPIs incorporate dose counters to show the number of doses used, or the number of doses remaining.
    • DPIs do not require the person to breathe in and press the inhaler at the same time, so are suitable when coordination and dexterity is a problem. 
    • DPIs are generally more expensive than pMDIs (plus spacer), but are no more effective. 
    • DPIs are usually larger than pMDIs, but can usually still fit in a pocket. 
  • Breath-actuated MDIs (BA-MDIs)
    • These are automatically activated on inhalation (the person needs to have sufficient inspiratory effort to activate the device). 
    • BA-MDIs are as effective as pMDIs and are useful when coordination and dexterity is a problem as there is no need to breathe in and press the inhaler at the same time. 
  • Nebulizers
    • Solutions are administered over 5–10 minutes from a nebulizer, usually driven by oxygen, which converts the solution into an aerosol that can be inhaled through a mask or mouthpiece. 
      • A mouthpiece is preferable to avoid adverse effects caused by exposure of the skin and eyes to the corticosteroid. 
    • Their main advantage is that no coordination is required by the user, and high doses of drug can be delivered directly to the airways. 
    • Nebulized corticosteroids are reserved for when inhaled treatment is inadequate.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma [BTS/SIGN, 2019], a large Health Technology Assessment (HTA) Comparison of the effectiveness of inhaler devices in asthma and chronic obstructive airways disease: a systematic review of the literature [Brocklebank, 2001], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in over 16s: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2019b], the NICE technology appraisal Inhaler devices for routine treatment of chronic asthma in older children (aged 5–15 years) [NICE, 2002], the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) Global strategy for asthma management and prevention [GINA, 2020], and the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I consider when choosing a delivery system for inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• When choosing a delivery system for inhaled corticosteroids, consider:
    • The ability of the person to develop and maintain an effective technique with the specific device — this may depend on factors such as age, physical barriers (for example, arthritis, muscle weakness), other medical conditions (for example, impaired vision), coordination, cognitive impairment, and inspiratory flow (a minimum inspiratory flow rate is required for use of dry powder inhalers [DPIs] or breath-actuated metered-dose inhalers [BA-MDIs]).
      • For children aged under 3 years, the preferred device is a pressurized metered-dose inhaler (pMDI) with spacer and face mask.
      • For children aged 3–5 years, the preferred device is pMDI with spacer and a mouthpiece (if they are able to demonstrate good technique). 
    • The suitability of the device to the person's (and carer’s) lifestyle, including portability and convenience. 
    • The person's preference for, and willingness to use, a particular device. 
    • Other inhalers the person is using — minimize the number of inhalers and the number of different types of inhaler used by each person as far as possible. 
    • Cost — if more than one device is suitable, choose the device with the lowest overall cost (taking into account the daily required dose and product price per dose). 
  • Only prescribe the inhaler after the person (and/or their carer) has received training in its use and has demonstrated a satisfactory technique. 
    • Review the person's inhaler technique and give advice about inhaler technique: 
      • At every consultation relating to an asthma attack.
      • When there is deterioration in control.
      • When the device is changed.
      • At every annual review.
      • If the person asks for it to be checked.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma [BTS/SIGN, 2019], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in over 16s: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2019b], the NICE guideline Asthma: diagnosis, monitoring and chronic asthma management [NICE, 2020c], the NICE technology appraisal Inhaler devices for routine treatment of chronic asthma in older children (aged 5–15 years) [NICE, 2002], and the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) Global strategy for asthma management and prevention [GINA, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What contraindications and cautions are associated with inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Contraindications
    • There are no contraindications to the use of inhaled corticosteroids.
  • Cautions
    • Active (untreated) or quiescent tuberculosis.
    • Untreated fungal, bacterial, parasitic, or systemic viral infections, or ocular herpes simplex.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the manufacturers' Summary of Product Characteristics for Clenil Modulite [ABPI, 2019a], Flixotide Evohaler [ABPI, 2020], Asmanex Twisthaler [ABPI, 2017c], and Pulmicort Turbohaler [ABPI, 2017b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Can I prescribe inhaled corticosteroids to a woman who is pregnant or breastfeeding?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pregnancy
    • Inhaled corticosteroids can be used as normal at any stage in pregnancy.
  • Breastfeeding
    • Inhaled corticosteroids can be used by women who are breastfeeding.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Pregnancy
  • These recommendations are based on the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], the UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) document Inhaled corticosteroids in pregnancy [UKTIS, 2016], and the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma.
    • No significant association has been demonstrated between major congenital malformations or adverse perinatal outcome and exposure to inhaled corticosteroids [BTS/SIGN, 2019].
Breastfeeding
  • These recommendations are based on the BNF [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020] and the Drugs and Lactation Database (LactMed).
    • The amounts of inhaled corticosteroids absorbed into the maternal bloodstream and excreted into breastmilk are probably too small to affect a breastfed infant [LactMed, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Local adverse effects of inhaled corticosteroids include:
    • Oral candidiasis, altered taste, dysphonia, hoarseness. 
    • Paradoxical bronchospasm — uncommon. It is characterized by an immediate increase in wheezing after dosing. 
    • Rash — if the inhaled corticosteroid is administered through a face mask or nebulizer a steroid rash (reddening and atrophy) may develop on the nose and around the mouth. 
  • Systemic adverse effects — these occur rarely and are much less likely to occur than with oral corticosteroids and are associated with high doses and prolonged use. 
    • Systemic adverse effects include:
      • Adrenal suppression — for signs and symptoms of adrenal suppression, see the section on Adrenal insufficiency in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.
      • Behavioural changes, sleep disorders, depression, aggression (predominantly in children). 
      • Cataracts, glaucoma, central serous chorioretinopathy.
      • Bruising. 
      • Increased susceptibility to infection — for example, upper respiratory tract infections, and pneumonia in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD).
      • Reduced bone mineral density. 
    • In children systemic adverse effects may be associated with doses of over 800 micrograms of beclometasone diproprionate equivalent or more per day (medium doses and above) and include: 
      • Adrenal suppression — this has been reported very rarely in children taking long-term inhaled corticosteroids and can occur even at standard doses.
      • Growth retardation — monitor the height of children receiving prolonged treatment with inhaled corticosteroids annually. 
    • For more information on the systemic adverse effects of corticosteroids, see the section on Adverse effects in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is based on the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma [BTS/SIGN, 2019], the British National Formulary [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) Global strategy for asthma management and prevention [GINA, 2020], the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) drug safety update Corticosteroids: rare risk of central serous chorioretinopathy with local as well as systemic administration [MHRA, 2017], and the manufacturers' Summary of Product Characteristics for Clenil Modulite [ABPI, 2019a], Flixotide Evohaler [ABPI, 2020], Asmanex Twisthaler [ABPI, 2017c], and Pulmicort Turbohaler [ABPI, 2017b].

Systemic adverse effects

  • Systemic adverse effects of corticosteroids are caused by swallowing some of the dose after deposition on the oropharynx (as well as from systemic absorption from the lungs). Fluticasone, mometasone, and ciclesonide are poorly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and undergo almost complete pre-systemic metabolism and so are less likely to cause systematic adverse effects [Ritter, 2020].

Risk of infections

  • A systematic review and meta-analysis of 17 randomized controlled trials (n = 15,336) that assessed the association between use of inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and the risk of upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) found that ICS use in people with asthma increases the risk of URTI [Yang, 2019]. 
  • A Cochrane systematic review of 43 studies (n = 31,397) that assessed the risk of pneumonia associated with fluticasone and budesonide for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) found that, either given alone, or in combination with a long-acting beta-2 agonist, they were associated with an increased risk of serious adverse pneumonia events, but neither significantly affected mortality compared with controls [Kew, 2014].
  • In COPD, high-dose ICS should not be used because of the risk of pneumonia [GINA, 2020].

Bone mineral density and fracture risk

  • Long-term use of ICS may reduce bone mineral density increasing the risk of fractures. However, the evidence is inconsistent, and the SIGN guideline Osteoporosis and the prevention of fragility fractures did not form a recommendation on fracture risk in people taking ICS [SIGN, 2015].
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials and 11 observational studies that looked at the association of long-term ICS and bone adverse effects in adults and children with asthma found no consistent evidence of serious skeletal harm from use of ICS [Loke, 2015a]. 
    • A systematic review meta-analysis of 16 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and seven observational studies in people with COPD found a small, but statistically significant dose-related increase in risk of fracture associated with long-term use of ICS [Loke, 2011]. 
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis of 13 studies and four RCTs did not show any association between use of ICS and increased risk of any fracture or hip fracture, although a slight increase in risk was noted among users of high-dose ICS [Etminan, 2008].

Adrenal suppression

  • Clinical adrenal insufficiency has been identified in a small number of children who have become acutely unwell at the time of intercurrent illness. Most of these children had been treated with high doses of ICS. The dose or duration of ICS treatment required to place a child at risk of clinical adrenal insufficiency is unknown, but is likely to occur at 800 micrograms beclometasone dipropionate equivalent per day or more [BTS/SIGN, 2019].
  • However, there is evidence that adrenal suppression may also occur in some children at lower doses [Kapadia, 2016].
    • Concomitant nasal corticosteroid use, low body mass index, and cumulative dose of ICS are contributing factors to the development of adrenal suppression.

Growth retardation

  • Although the effects of ICS on growth velocity are seen in pre-pubertal children in the first 1–2 years of treatment, this is not progressive or cumulative [GINA, 2020] — a systematic review and meta-analysis that examined the impact of ICS on growth in children found a difference of only 0.7% in adult height in ICS users compared with non-ICS users [Loke, 2015b].
  • A Cochrane systematic review of 25 trials (n = 8471) that assessed the impact of ICS on the linear growth of children with persistent asthma found that regular use of ICS at low or medium daily doses was associated with a mean reduction of 0.48 cm/year in linear growth velocity and 0.61 cm change from baseline in height during a 1-year treatment period in children with moderate persistent asthma. Other findings included [Zhang, 2014]: 
    • The effect size was associated more strongly with the ICS molecule than with the device or dose (in the low to medium range) — both beclometasone and budesonide produced a greater reduction in mean linear growth velocity (0.91 cm/year and 0.59 cm/year, respectively) compared with ciclesonide (0.08 cm/year), flunisolide (0.22 cm/year), fluticasone (0.39 cm/year), and mometasone (0.47 cm/year). 
    • ICS-induced growth suppression was maximal during the first year of therapy and less pronounced in subsequent years.
  • A Cochrane systematic review that assessed whether increasing the dose of ICS was associated with linear growth, weight gain, and skeletal maturation in children with asthma, and compared studies reporting linear growth over 12 months that used beclomethasone, budesonide, ciclesonide, fluticasone, or mometasone as monotherapy or as combination therapy with a long-acting beta-2 agonist at low (50 to 100 micrograms) versus low to medium (200 micrograms) doses of hydrofluoroalkane (HFA)-beclomethasone equivalent over 12–52 weeks, found that in four trials reporting the main outcomes [Pruteanu, 2014]:
    • There was a small but statistically significant group difference in growth velocity in the higher dose group — 5.74 cm/year, compared with 5.94 cm/year in lower dose ICS.
    • The choice of ICS molecule (mometasone, ciclesonide, or fluticasone) did not affect the level of growth velocity response.
  • Poorly controlled asthma itself adversely affects growth and final adult height [GINA, 2020]. 
  • The minor growth risks associated with ICS use are outweighed by the respiratory benefits [Kapadia, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I minimize the risks of adverse effects in people using inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• To minimize the adverse effects of inhaled corticosteroids:
    • Ensure that the dose of inhaled corticosteroid is titrated to the lowest dose at which effective control of symptoms is achieved. If adequate control of symptoms is not achieved, consider using add-on treatments rather than increasing the dose of inhaled corticosteroid. For more information see the CKS topic on Asthma. 
    • Avoid a rapid reduction in corticosteroid dose after prolonged use to reduce the risk of adrenal insufficiency — in adults who are stable on a high dose, consider halving the dose every 3 months.
    • Prescribe a large-volume spacer with a pressurized metered-dose inhaler (pMDI) for all children aged under 5 years and in all other people taking high doses of inhaled corticosteroids.
  • Oral candidiasis — advise the person to use a spacer and rinse their mouth with water after using an inhaler, this will also help to reduce systemic absorption of corticosteroid as a result of ingestion.
    • An antifungal oral suspension or oral gel can be used to treat oral candidiasis without discontinuing corticosteroid therapy.
  • Paradoxical bronchospasm — advise people with mild bronchospasm to use a short-acting beta-2 agonist before the inhaled corticosteroid, or switch from a pMDI to a dry powder inhaler (DPI). If it is severe, discontinue the inhaled corticosteroid and seek specialist advice.
  • Facial rash — advise that the skin and the mouth should be cleaned shortly after inhalation. 
  • In children receiving prolonged treatment with a high-dose inhaled corticosteroid:
    • Be alert to the symptoms of adrenal suppression, such as fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, headache, nausea, and vomiting, especially during times of illness. For more information, see the section on Adrenal insufficiency in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.
    • Monitor height regularly and accurately using a growth chart — growth velocity may be lower in the first 1–2 years of treatment. If there is a reduction of growth rate reduce the dose if possible, and/or refer to a paediatrician if required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma [BTS/SIGN, 2019], the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) Global strategy for asthma management and prevention [GINA, 2020], and the manufacturers' Summary of Product Characteristics for Clenil Modulite [ABPI, 2019a] and Flixotide Evohaler [ABPI, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions with inhaled corticosteroids and how should I manage them?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Drug interactions are rare in people taking inhaled corticosteroids, as systemic corticosteroid concentrations are usually low. However, in people taking high doses of inhaled corticosteroids for prolonged periods, systemic corticosteroid concentrations may be sufficiently high for interactions to become significant.
  • Antidiabetics (alogliptin, canagliflozin, glibenclamide, liraglutide, metformin) — the blood-glucose-lowering effects of antidiabetics are opposed by oral corticosteroids and high-dose corticosteroids may have a similar effect. Increase monitoring of diabetic control in people requiring high-dose inhaled corticosteroids and consider reducing the dose of the inhaled corticosteroids or adjusting the dose of antidiabetic medicine if necessary. 
  • If the person is taking a drug known to inhibit cytochrome P450, be aware that the metabolism of the inhaled corticosteroid may be inhibited, leading to an increased risk of adverse effects — beclometasone is less dependent on P450 (CYP3A) and may be a suitable alternative.  
    • Antiretrovirals (ritonavir, saquinavir) — concurrent treatment is not recommended as there is potential for an interaction even with inhaled corticosteroids. If concurrent treatment is necessary, monitor for corticosteroid adverse effects (such as moon face, weight gain, hyperglycaemia).
      • Beclometasone can cause hypokalaemia that might be additive with the effects of saquinavir. Monitor potassium levels closely. 
    • Cobicistat — concurrent treatment is not recommended as there is potential for an interaction even with inhaled corticosteroids. If concurrent treatment is necessary, monitor for corticosteroid adverse effects. 
    • Azole antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole) — be alert for any unexpected increase in corticosteroid adverse effects.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the textbook Stockley's Drug Interactions [Preston, 2020], the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) drug safety update Cobicistat, ritonavir and coadministration with a steroid: risk of systemic corticosteroid adverse effects [MHRA, 2016], and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics for Clenil Modulite [ABPI, 2019a], Alvesco Inhaler [ABPI, 2017a], and Symbicort Turbohaler [ABPI, 2019b].

Antiretrovirals and inhaled corticosteroids
  • Coadministration of a HIV treatment boosting agent with a CYP3A-metabolized corticosteroid is not recommended unless the potential benefit to the patient outweighs the risk, in which case patients should be monitored for systemic corticosteroid-related reactions [MHRA, 2016].
    • If coadministration is necessary, use of beclomethasone should be considered where possible — particularly for long-term use. Beclomethasone is less dependent on CYP3A metabolism, and, although the risk of an interaction leading to adverse corticosteroid effects may not be completely removed, it may be lower.
  • Beclometasone is less dependent on CYP3A metabolism than some other corticosteroids, and, in general, interactions are unlikely, however, the possibility of systemic effects with concomitant use of strong CYP3A inhibitors cannot be excluded [ABPI, 2019a].
Azole antifungals and inhaled corticosteroids
  • The manufacturers of Alvesco Inhaler [ABPI, 2017a] and Symbicort Turbohaler [ABPI, 2019b] recommend that concurrent use with potent cytochrome P450 inhibitors (CYP450), such as azole antifungals, should be avoided, unless the benefits outweigh the risk of systemic adverse effects. 
    • If short–term treatment with a CYP450 inhibitor is necessary, the time interval between administration of the inhibitor and Symbicort Turbohaler should be as long as possible [ABPI, 2019b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give to a person receiving inhaled corticosteroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person taking inhaled corticosteroids (ICS):
    • On the importance of using the correct inhaler technique, and how to take care of the device.
      • To check and remove the mouthpiece cover properly before inhaling a dose and to shake the inhaler to remove loose objects that may have become trapped during storage. 
      • To replace the inhaler cover immediately after use and to ensure it clicks into place. 
      • To clean the device according to the manufacturer's instructions. 
    • On the importance of attending for regular review, including monitoring of growth in children.
    • That their treatment needs to be taken regularly (usually twice daily), long term, and that there will be no immediate noticeable effect on their symptoms.
    • That adherence to the treatment will lead to better control of the condition and decrease the risk of complications.
    • That if they are using a spacer device, they should always use the same type and not switch between spacers as they are not inter-compatible.
      • The spacer device should be cleaned regularly in warm water that can contain a mild detergent, or a sterilising solution used to clean babies' bottles. It should then be allowed to air dry. 
      • Spacer devices should be replaced after 12 months. 
      • Not to share inhaler devices or spacers with family members. 
    • That smoking can reduce the effectiveness of ICS. 
    • To rinse their mouth with water after inhaling each dose to reduce the risk of oral candidiasis and systemic absorption. 
    • If the person has never had chickenpox and is taking high-dose ICS, to avoid people with chickenpox or shingles, and to seek medical advice if they come into contact with an affected person. 
    • To be aware of the symptoms of adrenal insufficiency and seek immediate medical attention if they experience them. For more information, see the section on Adrenal insufficiency in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral. 
    • To carry a steroid treatment card if they are receiving long-term treatment with high doses. 
      • This provides clear guidance on the precautions to minimize the risks of adverse effects, and provides details of the prescriber, drug, dosage, and the duration of treatment.
    • GP practices can obtain supplies through their Primary Care Support England.
    • Advise people taking ICS of the possible adverse effects and ways to minimize them.
  • COVID-19
    • The advice for people using inhaled steroids for any indication is to continue at the prescribed dose in order to optimise the control of their condition.
    • Explain to people that there is no evidence that treatment with ICS increases the risk associated with COVID‑19.
    • Advise those people who are using ICS regularly to continue to use them and delay any planned trials of withdrawal of ICS.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Thoracic Society (BTS) and Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) British guideline on the management of asthma [BTS/SIGN, 2019], the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) Global strategy for asthma management and prevention [GINA, 2020], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in over 16s: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2019b], the British National Formulary [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) drug safety update Pressurised metered dose inhalers (pMDI): risk of airway obstruction from aspiration of loose objects [MHRA, 2018], and the patient information leaflet for Volumatic Adult Spacer [ABPI, 2018].

Cleaning spacers
  • The manufacturers of the Volumatic spacer advises people to clean spacers at least twice weekly [ABPI, 2018]. However, NICE advises that cleaning should be carried out no more than once monthly as more frequent cleaning affects their performance because of build up of static [NICE, 2019b].  
Chickenpox and measles
  • People taking high-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) should be issued with a steroid treatment card [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]. 
    • The steroid treatment card advises people that have never had chickenpox to avoid people with chickenpox or shingles, and to seek medical advice if they come into contact with an infected person. The BNF states that this advice should also apply to measles. 
    • The steroid treatment card does not make a distinction between oral corticosteroids and ICS, and while the BNF advises that this advice applies to people receiving oral or parenteral corticosteroids, it does not extend this advice to people taking ICS. 
    • CKS could find no evidence that people taking high-dose ICS are at increased risk from chickenpox, so the recommendation to provide advice to avoid people with chickenpox or shingles if they are taking high-dose ICS is pragmatic as high-dose ICS may cause immunosuppression [BTS/SIGN, 2019].
COVID-19
  • The recommendation to continue using ICS during the COVID-19 pandemic is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) COVID-19 rapid guideline: community-based care of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) [NICE, 2020a] and COVID-19 rapid guideline: severe asthma NICE guideline [NICE, 2020b]. 
    • The recommendation to continue using ICS in COPD is based on NICE guidelines that advise that ‘there is some evidence that use of ICS in COPD may increase the overall risk of pneumonia this risk alone should not be used as a reason to change treatment in those established on ICS’ as this may cause a resultant risk and destabilisation of COPD management.
